title: Examples of presentations
text:
Here we can add links to presentations.
For now you can access the presentation by adjusting the URL below with your details
https://Giorgalla.github.io/course-website-02/tab-presentation/presentation1/presentation-example.html
Simply change my capitalized text for your: i) your github username
ii) the name of your github repo then copy the URL and paste it to visit the webpage.
The adjusted URL above should take you to an example of a simple Quarto presentation.

title: Decision Making Process
text: The decision-making process is a systematic approach to choosing the best course of action among multiple alternatives to achieve a desired outcome. It typically involves identifying the problem, gathering information, evaluating options, and making a choice followed by implementation and review. ## Add an image

title: Decision Making Process

It typically involves identifying the problem, gathering information, evaluating options, and making a choice followed by implementation and review. ## Add an image

title: Survey Data Analysis
text:
# Create data tables
# Create Codebook
codebook <- tibble(
  variable_name = c("age", "gender", "education", "decision_factor", "decision_fatigue", "overanalysis", "decision_style", "cognitive_bias", "decision_strategies", "decision_confidence"),
  question = c(
    "What is your age?",
    "What is your gender?",
    "What is your education level?",
    "When making a decision, which factor influences you the most?",
    "How often do you experience decision fatigue?",
    "Do you tend to overanalyze decisions before making them?",
    "Which type of decision-making style best describes you?",
    "Have you ever experienced cognitive bias affecting your decisions?",
    "What strategies do you use to improve your decision-making process?",
    "On a scale from 1-5, how confident are you in your decision-making skills?"
  )
)

# Generate a synthetic dataset
set.seed(123)
data <- tibble(
  age = sample(18:65, 100, replace = TRUE),
  gender = sample(c("Male", "Female", "Non-binary", "Prefer not to say"), 100, replace = TRUE),
  education = sample(c("High school or below", "Undergraduate degree", "Graduate degree", "Other"), 100, replace = TRUE),
  decision_factor = sample(c("Logical reasoning", "Emotions and intuition", "Social influences", "Past experiences"), 100, replace = TRUE),
  decision_fatigue = sample(c("Never", "Sometimes", "Often", "Always"), 100, replace = TRUE),
  overanalysis = sample(c("Yes", "No", "Sometimes"), 100, replace = TRUE),
  decision_style = sample(c("Rational", "Intuitive", "Dependent", "Avoidant"), 100, replace = TRUE),
  cognitive_bias = sample(c("Yes", "No", "Unsure"), 100, replace = TRUE),
  decision_strategies = sample(c("Seeking advice", "Analyzing pros and cons", "Taking time", "Relying on past experiences"), 100, replace = TRUE),
  decision_confidence = sample(1:5, 100, replace = TRUE)
)

title: Survey Data Analysis
text:
Age Distribution

# Age distribution
age_plot <- ggplot(data, aes(x = age)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 5, fill = "steelblue", color = "black") +
  labs(title = "Age Distribution", x = "Age", y = "Frequency") +
  theme_minimal()

age_plot

title: Survey Data Analysis
text:
Linear regression plot

# Linear regression plot
regression_plot <- ggplot(data, aes(x = age, y = decision_confidence)) +
  geom_point(color = "blue", alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", color = "red", se = FALSE) +
  labs(
    title = "Linear Regression: Age vs Decision Confidence",
    x = "Age",
    y = "Decision Confidence (1-5)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

regression_plot

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Survey Data Analysis
text:
histogram_age_decision_fatigue

# Histogram of age with decision fatigue as fill
histogram_age_decision_fatigue <- ggplot(data, aes(x = age, fill = decision_fatigue)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 5, color = "black", alpha = 0.7) +
  labs(
    title = "Age Distribution by Decision Fatigue",
    x = "Age",
    y = "Frequency",
    fill = "Decision Fatigue"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

histogram_age_decision_fatigue

title: Survey Data Analysis
text:
box_plot_decision_confidence_gender

# Box plot for decision confidence by gender
box_plot_decision_confidence_gender <- ggplot(data, aes(x = gender, y = decision_confidence, fill = gender)) +
  geom_boxplot(color = "black") +
  labs(
    title = "Decision Confidence by Gender",
    x = "Gender",
    y = "Decision Confidence"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1), legend.position = "none")

box_plot_decision_confidence_gender

title: Survey Data Analysis
text:
Correlation plot

# Compute the correlation matrix
correlation_matrix <- cor(encoded_data, use = "complete.obs", method = "pearson")

# Reshape the correlation matrix for plotting
correlation_long <- reshape2::melt(correlation_matrix)

# Plot the heatmap
full_correlation_heatmap <- ggplot(correlation_long, aes(x = Var1, y = Var2, fill = value)) +
  geom_tile(color = "white") +
  scale_fill_gradient2(low = "darkblue", high = "lightblue", mid = "white", midpoint = 0, limit = c(-1, 1)) +
  labs(
    title = "Full Correlation Heatmap",
    x = "Variables",
    y = "Variables",
    fill = "Correlation"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

full_correlation_heatmap

title: Course overview
text:
What is a Dashboard?

Dashboards provide a visual display of the most important information needed to achieve one or more objectives.
They consolidate and arrange information on a single screen.

Key Characteristics of Effective Dashboards

Clarity: Information should be easy to read and interpret.
Accuracy: Data must be accurate and up-to-date.
Relevance: Content should align with user goals and needs.

title: Course overview
text: Definition by Stephen Few

title: Course overview
text:
The Role of Visual Design

Minimize distractions and unnecessary elements.
Use consistent layouts and formatting.
Apply thoughtful use of color and typography.

Best Practices for Dashboard Design

Avoid clutter: Only display essential information.
Prioritize data: Highlight key metrics and KPIs.
Use visual hierarchy: Direct the viewer’s focus to the most important elements.

title: Course overview
text:
Common Pitfalls to Avoid

Overloading the user with too much data.
Using overly complex or inconsistent designs.
Neglecting the importance of user testing.

What You Shoud Do

Focus on the needs and goals of the dashboard’s end-users.
Iteratively test and refine designs to improve usability.

title: Course overview
text:
Summary

Dashboards are powerful tools for decision-making.
Effective dashboards balance clarity, relevance, and visual appeal.
Avoid common pitfalls by focusing on user needs and testing designs.
